Title: A body has been found in the search for a woman missing near a Pennsylvania sinkhole
Description: A Pennsylvania coroner's office said investigators believe they have located the body of 64-year-old Elizabeth Pollard, who was last seen four days earlier near a sinkhole above a shuttered coal mine. (Image credit: Matt Freed)

Title: She's 74 — and expecting: Wisdom the albatross astounds once again
Description: It started in the Eisenhower era: Every year, Wisdom, a Layan albatross, has returned to her nesting grounds on the Midway Atoll in the Pacific Ocean. (Image credit: Dan Rapp)

Title: After trying to impose martial law, South Korea's president faces an impeachment vote
Description: After President Yoon Suk Yeol's failed attempt to impose martial law, South Korea's parliament will vote Saturday on his impeachment. Yoon's own party chief has called for his powers to be suspended. (Image credit: Jung-Yeon-Je)

Title: Concerns over Trump's crypto promises. And, gift ideas for 5 personality types
Description: President-elect Donald Trump has promised to make the U.S. the planet's 'crypto capital.' Here's why critics are concerned. And, gift ideas this holiday season for five personality types. (Image credit: Omar Albam)

Title: The regime of Syrian President Bashar Assad is looking increasingly fragile
Description: Rebel insurgents swept into Hama as the Syrian army withdrew. The move puts the rebel fighters even closer to the Syrian capitol Damascus, and deals another blow to President Bashar Assad.

Title: A cancer survivor nearly died trying to prove he had recovered
Description: In this week's StoryCorps, two friends recall a harrowing ski trip in the Colorado mountains.

Title: New York City has a housing shortage. Officials are trying to change that
Description: Officials in New York City are close to approving zoning changes that could increase the amount of housing available. How will this impact housing availability and access?

Title: Police are still looking for the suspect in the shooting of the UnitedHealthcare CEO
Description: The manhunt for the person who fatally shot the head of one of the country's largest health insurers in New York City entered its third day Friday as police parsed newly discovered clues. (Image credit: Yuki Iwamura)

Title: Who or what else did President Biden pardon? Find out in the quiz!
Description: Also in your grab bag of weekly trivia: martial law, bitcoin, the first lady's holiday décor, a Kennedy who's not RFK Jr., brain rot and the popemobile.

Title: Syrian opposition forces enter a key city -- in a new blow to Assad regime
Description: In Syria, government forces retreat as rebels capture key cities. The rebels' stunning advance raises questions about the survival of the Bashar al-Assad regime.

Title: Minneapolis City Council explores options for George Floyd Square
Description: George Floyd's killing by police in 2020 sparked worldwide protests. Minneapolis wants to make changes to George Floyd Square -- the multi-block memorial that occupies the area where Floyd died.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Syrian opposition forces enter a key city, in a new blow to Assad regime. President-elect Trump announces White House AI and Crypto Czar. New York City takes a step toward addressing housing crisis.

Title: 3 climbers from the U.S. and Canada are believed to have died in New Zealand
Description: Three mountain climbers — two from the U.S. and one from Canada — missing for five days on Aoraki, New Zealand's tallest peak, are believed to have died in a fall, the authorities said Friday. (Image credit: Mark Baker)

Title: Trump names former Sen. David Perdue of Georgia to be ambassador to China
Description: With his nomination, Trump is leaning on a former business executive-turned politician to serve as the administration's envoy to America's most potent economic and military adversary.

Title: Trump nominates Rodney Scott to lead Customs and Border Protection
Description: Rodney Scott at CBP and Caleb Vitello at ICE would work alongside Stephen Miller, who was named deputy chief of staff for policy and Tom Homan, also tapped to be a 'border czar.' (Image credit: Matt York/AP)

Title: At Miami's Art Basel fair, elephants and a buried ship are bringing out the locals
Description: Rising from the sand on Miami Beach are what appear to be the sails of a buried Spanish galleon. It's a piece created by Tlingit/Unangax artist Nicholas Galanin. (Image credit: Greg Allen)

Title: Memphis police regularly violate civil rights, DOJ finds
Description: The Justice Department finds Memphis police regularly violate the civil rights of citizens, engaging in unconstitutional tactics like excessive use of force and discriminating against Black residents.

Title: Former detective weighs in on the hunt for the UnitedHealthcare CEO's killer
Description: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with David Sarni, a retired NYPD detective and adjunct professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, about the hunt for the gunman who killed the UnitedHealthcare CEO.

Title: Syrians in Aleppo show cautious optimism amid rebel takeover
Description: Syrians in Aleppo are cautiously optimistic as rebel groups take over Assad-regime held areas of their country.

Title: Protecting Unique Wilderness at the Bottom of the World
Description: Chile is poised to create it's 47th national part in the coming year, protecting wilderness at the southern tip of South America. That's thanks in large part to the work of a U.S. conservationist and her organization. We go to the bottom of the world to see the stunning landscape that will make up the park.

Title: Some rural Nevadans want Trump to stop the state's solar energy boom
Description: Backlash against massive solar energy farms drove strong rural turnout in Nevada may have helped flip the presidential vote there to Republican for the first time since 2004. But it's not a given Trump will derail President Biden's plans for more Nevada solar. (Image credit: Ethan Miller/Getty Images)

Title: France's toppled government adds to the European Union's bigger political problems
Description: The political instability in France — and simultaneously in Germany, where the governing coalition collapsed a month ago — could have wide-ranging consequences. (Image credit: Telmo Pinto)

Title: Search continues for the person who shot and killed UnitedHealthcare CEO
Description: The search continues for the person who shot and killed the CEO of UnitedHealthcare outside a Manhattan hotel yesterday. Police have said it was a target, pre-planned attack.

Title: Insurgents gain ground in Syria. What happens now?
Description: Syrian anti-government insurgents claim they have entered the city of Hama — a major Syrian government stronghold.This continues their momentum over the last week, when they also seized Syria's second largest city, Aleppo. Since the war started in 2011, half a million people have been killed and many millions of others displaced.The Syrian Civil War has been locked in a stalemate for years. Now, rebel forces are gaining ground against the oppressive regime of Bashar al-Assad. Will the group ultimately end his control over the country?For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.Email us at considerthis@npr...

Title: How worried should we be about Disease X?
Description: An unidentified illness has claimed 80 lives in DRC. Investigators are on the scenes to determine what it is — and how much of a threat it poses to locally and globally (Image credit: PeterHermesFurian/Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Title: Pope Francis goes electric in new eco-friendly popemobile
Description: Pope Francis, who heads the Catholic Church, has doubled down on his commitment to the environment with a new electric popemobile presented by Mercedes-Benz. (Image credit: Filippo Monteforte/AFP)

Title: A powerful 7.0 earthquake strikes off northern California coast; tsunami warning issued
Description: A powerful earthquake has struck off the northern California coast and a tsunami warning has been issued. Several aftershocks continue to rattle the area off Eureka. (Image credit: Jenny Kane)

Title: Court rejects Boeing plea deal stemming from 737 Max crashes
Description: A federal judge in Texas has rejected a plea deal between Boeing and the U.S. Justice Department, saying the court should play a bigger role in selecting an independent monitor to oversee the company. (Image credit: David Ryder)

Title: Memphis police use excessive force and discriminate against Black people, the DOJ finds
Description: A Justice Department investigation launched after the beating death of Tyre Nichols in 2023 found that 'Memphis police officers regularly violate the rights of the people they are sworn to serve.' (Image credit: Gerald Herbert)

Title: Cryptic words were found on bullet casings at scene of CEO Brian Thompson's killing
Description: Shell casings with the cryptic words 'deny,' 'defend' and 'depose' were found at the scene of the fatal shooting of the UnitedHealthcare CEO outside of a Manhattan hotel, police officials say. (Image credit: New York Police Department)

Title: Amnesty International accuses Israel of genocide in Gaza, which Israel strongly denies
Description: Amnesty International says Israel has sought to deliberately destroy Palestinians in its war with Hamas, by mounting deadly attacks, demolishing vital infrastructure and preventing aid deliveries. (Image credit: Fatima Shbair)

Title: Anthem plans to put time limits on anesthesia coverage, alarming doctors
Description: Anthem Blue Cross Blue Shield says it will put time limits on anesthesia care starting next year. Doctors and elected officials, including in New York and Connecticut, are asking it to change course. (Image credit: Michael Conroy)

Title: Syrian opposition forces enter the strategic city of Hama
Description: Syrian rebels have entered another major city, in a further blow to President Bashar Assad after they took over Aleppo days earlier. (Image credit: Omar Albam)

Title: Syrian opposition forces enter strategic city of Hama
Description: Syrian rebels have entered a second city in yet another blow to the President Bashar al-Assad after they took over Syria's second city only days before. (Image credit: Omar Albam)

Title: Post Hurricane Helene: People in western North Carolina feel the cold weather
Description: People displaced by Hurricane Helene and living in temporary shelters, are trying to stay warm this week as freezing temperatures blanket the region.

Title: The CEO of a health insurance giant is gunned down on a busy Manhattan street
Description: New York police say Brian Thompson, CEO of UnitedHealthcare, the country's largest health insurer, was the target of a preplanned attack. Authorities are searching for the person who did it.

Title: An unknown infant was rushed to a Gaza hospital. A nurse gave her a name, and a home
Description: The newborn, found by rescuers after an Israeli attack, was rushed to a hospital. Nurse Amal Abu Khatleh gave her the name Malak, meaning angel. She is raising the baby until relatives can be found. (Image credit: Amal Abu Khatleh)

Title: Long before this week, South Korea had a painful history with martial law
Description: In 1980, violent clashes between government forces and pro-democracy demonstrators in the southwestern city of Gwangju created lasting scars that continue to shape South Korea to this day. (Image credit: File)

Title: How a staffing shortage can make special education jobs more dangerous
Description: Special educators are more likely to experience violence or aggression from students. That can make hiring a challenge, at a time when schools nationwide are struggling to fill these positions. (Image credit: Samuel Rocha IV)

Title: Comparing the current protests in Georgia with Ukraine's 2014 revolution
Description: There are parallels between the demonstrations in the Republic of Georgia and Ukraine's 2014 revolution. One expert says while there are many similarities, there is one big difference to consider.

Title: French Prime Minister Michel Barnier and his cabinet lose no-confidence vote
Description: The French government has fallen in a no-confidence vote, and the prime minister is resigning. President Emmanuel Macron has cut short a trip to Saudi Arabia to return and address the nation.

Title: Lessons learned from when the Obama administration deported millions of people
Description: Could deporting immigrants open up their jobs for Americans? President Obama's administration deported more than 3 million people, and an economist studied those effects.

Title: Why access to abortion in Missouri is in limbo
Description: Missouri voters moved to end the state's strict abortion ban in the November election but it's unclear whether the treatment will be available Thursday, the deadline for the amendment to take effect.

Title: Why a Florida Democrat joined the DOGE caucus that's looking to cut federal spending
Description: Democratic Rep. Jared Moskowitz of Florida tells Morning Edition that members of his party need to be in the room when conversations about cutting government spending and efficiency are happening. (Image credit: Jose Luis Magana)

Title: Amnesty International is officially calling Israel's war in Gaza a genocide
Description: The human rights group says Israel acted with intent to commit genocide against Palestinians, alongside its war against Hamas.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Donald Trump's pick for defense secretary fights to save nomination. Manhunt is underway in NYC for the person who killed UnitedHealthcare's CEO. How would mass deportations affect U.S. job market?

Title: The Black Gate: Vanished in the Night
Description: In the Xinjiang region of western China, the government has rounded up and detained hundreds of thousands of Uyghurs and other Muslim ethnic groups, including the wife and young children of a Uyghur businessman named Abdullatif Kucar. NPR correspondent Emilly Feng follows Kucar as he desperately searches for his missing family. To listen to this series sponsor-free and support NPR, sign up for Embedded+ in Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Title: Mexican troops seize a record fentanyl haul in northern Sinaloa state
Description: Mexican soldiers and marines have seized over a ton of fentanyl pills in two raids in the north, with officials calling it the biggest catch of the synthetic opioid in the country's history. (Image credit: Martin Urista)

Title: Legendary Medellin cartel drug lord released from U.S. prison after serving 25 years
Description: One of Colombia's legendary drug lords has been released from prison and is expected to be deported. Ochoa was first indicted in the U.S. for his alleged role in the 1986 killing of a DEA informant. (Image credit: AP)

Title: A major power plant fails in Cuba, plunging the island into darkness — again
Description: The blackout, on Wednesday, affected the entire nation, leaving millions without electricity and forcing authorities to suspend classes and work activities indefinitely. (Image credit: Ramon Espinosa)

Title: Trump is already making foreign policy plans
Description: Every time a presidential transition takes place, a familiar phrase crops up: 'the U.S. has one president at a time.' But Trump is already declaring foreign policy plans that differ from Biden's.

Title: The U.S. and China Vie for Influence in Africa
Description: Joe Biden's first and last trip to Africa as president wrapped up in a port city in Angola. It's the end of an 800 mile train line connecting the port to massive mineral deposits in Central Africa. The U.S. and other Western countries are raising billions to upgrade the rail line, a move that is seen as an effort to counter China's investments in mining in the region. We go to one of the mining cities along that train route to see how the geopolitics are playing out. Support NPR and get sponsor-free episodes of State of the World. Sign up for NPR+ at plus.npr.org

Title: The killing of the UnitedHealthcare CEO was a targeted attack, authorities say
Description: The CEO of United Healthcare was shot and killed in what New York City officials are calling a brazen and targeted attack. The company has the largest share of the nation's health insurance market.

Title: French lawmakers oust the prime minister after just 91 days, toppling the government
Description: France's government has been toppled by a no-confidence vote in parliament, for the first time sine 1962. Prime Minister Michel Barnier served the shortest time in the post in France's modern history. (Image credit: Michel Euler)

Title: Who is Brian Thompson, the UnitedHealthcare CEO gunned down in New York?
Description: Thompson, a 50-year-old father of two, spent two decades at UnitedHealth Group before his shocking death. Tributes are pouring in from coworkers and public officials in his home state of Minnesota. (Image credit: Stefan Jeremiah)

Title: Longer careers in ice hockey are linked to a greater risk of CTE, a new study finds
Description: A new Boston University study of 77 deceased male ice hockey players found that their chances of developing the degenerative brain disease known as CTE increased with each year they played the sport. (Image credit: Patrick Smith)

Title: Supreme Court appears skeptical of challenge to ban on gender-affirming care for minors
Description: At issue is a state law in Tennessee that blocks minors from accessing gender-affirming care in the state. (Image credit: Saul Loeb)

Title: What Trump's 2nd term might mean for the country's economy
Description: Economist David Wessel talks about Trump's plans on tariffs and tax cuts, and the potential economic impact of Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy's Department of Government Efficiency.

Title: Montana lawmakers cross the aisle to block a trans bathroom ban in the state capitol
Description: Some Republicans joined Democrats in rejecting the measure, which would have restricted bathroom access. Rep. Zooey Zephyr, Montana's first openly transgender legislator, won a second term last month. (Image credit: Tommy Martino)

Title: South Korea's president faces calls to be impeached. And, tips to avoid porch pirates
Description: South Korea's president faces calls to resign or to be impeached after he briefly imposed martial law over the country. And, tips on how to avoid falling victim to porch pirates this holiday season. (Image credit: Anthony Wallace)

Title: South Korea's president faces calls to resign or be impeached
Description: Opposition parties have filed a motion to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol and plans for rallies in major cities are underway. (Image credit: Chung Sung-Jun)

Title: D.R. Congo's mining capital is at the heart of Biden's bid to counter China in Africa
Description: Kolwezi has some of the world's largest copper and cobalt reserves and that makes it a key location at the heart of the U.S. and China's jostle for mineral supremacy on the African continent. (Image credit: Junior Kannah)

Title: Hani Almadhoun remembers when he and his late brother started Gaza Soup Kitchen
Description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks to Hani Almadhoun about the death of his brother Mahmoud, who ran a soup kitchen in Gaza.

Title: Israel threatens a wider war on Lebanon if a truce with Hezbollah fails
Description: NPR's Leila Fadel talks to Rima Korjieh, Lutheran World Relief project officer in Lebanon, about families returning to their homes after the ceasefire with Israel was announced.

Title: Guardian' journalists strike to protest sale of sister paper 'Observer'
Description: Nearly 500 journalists have walked out of the Guardian and its sister paper, the Observer, to protest what they see as a betrayal of the paper's values: the planned sale of the Observer to a startup. (Image credit: Oli Scarff/Getty Images)

Title: Supreme Court hears challenge to law banning gender-affirming care for trans kids
Description: At issue is a Tennessee law that bans access to hormones, puberty blockers, and other treatments for trans kids in the state. (Image credit: Kent Nishimura)

Title: Inside RFK Jr.'s nonprofit's legal battles over vaccines and public health
Description: The nonprofit Children's Health Defense that Kennedy led has filed nearly 30 federal and state lawsuits since 2020, many challenging vaccines and public health mandates. (Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

Title: The government in France could fall if a no-confidence vote succeeds
Description: The French government faces the no-confidence vote over the prime minister's austerity budget. He's been in office less than three months.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: South Korea's opposition politicians submit a motion to impeach the president. The U.S. Supreme Court to hear case involving gender affirming care. The French government faces a no-confidence vote.

Title: Congo's mining capital is at the center of U.S. bid to counter China in Africa
Description: Kolwezi in the Democratic Republic of Congo, has some of the worlds largest copper and cobalt reserves and that makes it one of the key locations at the heart of the US and China's jostle for mineral supremacy on the African continent.

Title: Mother of Michigan school shooter asks for her conviction to be thrown out
Description: Jennifer Crumbley, the mother of the teenager who killed four classmates at Michigan's Oxford High School three years ago, wants her involuntary manslaughter conviction overturned.

Title: How George Soros forced the UK to devalue the pound
Description: As people learn more about Donald Trump's pick for Treasury Secretary, Scott Bessent, one story comes up over and over: a legendary trade that he played a small part in while he worked at George Soros' hedge fund in the 1990s. In 1992, Soros' fund set its sights on the British pound, betting that some time in the fall of that year, the pound would plummet in value. Opposing them in this trade was the Bank of England, which was determined to keep its currency stable. The financial battle that followed was intense and proved to be a watershed moment in the balance of power between markets and governments.On today's show, we speak to Robert Johnson, a former managing director at Soros' fund, for a blow-by-blow account of those fateful days in 1992. This episode was...

Title: Search goes into the night for Pennsylvania woman who may have fallen into a sinkhole
Description: A grandmother looking for her lost cat apparently fell into a sinkhole that had recently opened above an abandoned coal mine and rescuers worked late into Tuesday night to try and find her. (Image credit: Gene J. Puskar)

Title: To many residents in southern Lebanon, life doesn't feel like there's a ceasefire
Description: Israel's military has imposed a curfew and created a no-go zone where villagers are prohibited from going home to villages across southern Lebanon. NPR speaks to residents inside.

Title: A freelance journalist describes the scene after rebels seized Aleppo
Description: NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with Sara Kassim, a freelance reporter in Aleppo about the situation on the ground after opposition forces have captured large swaths of land in the area.

Title: Toy companies are worried about Trump's threat of steep tariffs
Description: Nearly all toys sold in the U.S. are imported -- mostly from China. Toys were largely spared from tariffs during Trump's first term. But toymakers and their customers may not be so lucky next year.

Title: A Danish museum agrees to return a bronze sculpture looted from Turkey
Description: A Danish museum has agreed to return the bronze head of a Roman Emperor to Turkey. The sculpture was among thousands of artifacts looted from Turkey and sold to American and European museums.

Title: Will Trump's next term make him richer?
Description: Just before Donald Trump took office the first time, he held a press conference, announcing that he would turn over control of his business empire to his sons. He said he wanted to address concerns about conflicts of interest even though he maintained he didn't really have to. Saying, 'I could actually run my business. I could actually run my business and run government at the same time. I don't like the way that looks, but I would be able to do that if I wanted to.'Trump's second term may put that theory to the test. The former and future president hasn't yet announced any plan to wall himself off from his businesses while in office, and Trump's businesses like his many hotels and resorts could benefit substantially from his actions as President.For sponsor-free ep...

Title: What on Earth is Happening In South Korea?
Description: In a shocking turn of events, martial law was declared late at night by the president of South Korea, giving him extraordinary powers. Then after protests and an act of parliament, the order was reversed seven hours later. To try to understand what is happening with this key U.S. ally and trading partner, we hear from NPR's correspondent in Seoul. (Image credit: Chung Sung-Jun)

Title: Putin's planes took Ukrainian kids into 'coerced' Russian adoption, a Yale report says
Description: Russia's president and senior Kremlin officials financed and facilitated the transport of at least 314 Ukrainian children into 'coerced' foster care and adoptions, a new Yale University report says. (Image credit: Alexander Kazakov)

Title: South Korea's lawmakers vote to lift the president's martial law declaration
Description: South Korean lawmakers voted unanimously to reverse President Yoon Suk Yeol's declaration of an 'emergency martial law' on Tuesday. Yoon had accused the opposition of anti-state activities. (Image credit: Anthony Wallace)

Title: As Israel bans UNRWA, Palestinians stand to lose schools and clinics, not only in Gaza
Description: Israel is severing ties with the main United Nations agency that provides aid to Palestinians. With the focus largely on Gaza, the move also threatens key services in the occupied West Bank. (Image credit: Afif H. Amireh for NPR)

Title: Rebels in Syria control Aleppo and push toward Damascus
Description: NPR's Leila Fadel talks to Robert Ford, former U.S. ambassador to Syria, about what it means for the region.

Title: J. Edgar Hoover made the FBI his personal weapon. Kash Patel could try doing it again
Description: Trump's pick to lead the FBI may test internal guardrails, historian and J. Edgar Hoover biographer Beverly Gage tells Morning Edition. (Image credit: Alex Brandon)

Title: U.S. will send Ukraine $725 million more in arms
Description: President Joe Biden has pledged to spend all of the military assistance funds Congress approved this year for Ukraine before the end of his administration on Jan. 20, 2025. (Image credit: Oleg Petrasiuk)

Title: California Democratic leaders aim to fight policies of incoming Trump administration
Description: At the call of Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom, the California Legislature took a step toward preparing for legal battles with the incoming Trump administration.

Title: The Gaza war has shaken up the Mideast. Now Syria's war has reignited
Description: Rebels have rekindled Syria's war with a lightning offensive that seemed to come from nowhere. But multiple upheavals, beginning with the Gaza war last year, have spread conflict across the region. (Image credit: Omar Albam)

Title: Tis the season for porch pirates. Here are some tips to help protect your items
Description: Retailers are warning Americans to be vigilant about their packages and not let porch pirates steal the holiday spirit, (Image credit: Mark Lennihan)

Title: Teens can't get off their phones. Here's what some schools are doing about it
Description: Teens spend much of their days on their phones — many of them during school. Here's how schools and teachers are trying to fix that. (Image credit: Emily Brisse, Mitchell Rutherford and Abbey Osborn)

Title: Trump picks staunch Israel supporters for key roles worrying Arab Americans
Description: President-elect Donald Trump flipped the blue city of Dearborn, Mich., with a promise to end the wars in the Middle East. As his administration begins to take shape, some residents are concerned.

Title: State Department aims to get more career ambassadors in place before 2nd Trump term
Description: As the transition to a new administration approaches, what is the likely impact on a decidedly nervous State Department?

Title: Morning news brief
Description: What's it mean for Biden's legacy now that he's pardoned his son. Examining the rapid advance by rebel fighters in Syria. Protesters take to the streets of the former Soviet republic of Georgia.

Title: Negotiators fail to reach an agreement on a plastic pollution treaty. Talks to resume next year
Description: The negotiations in Busan, South Korea, were supposed to be the fifth and final round to produce the first legally binding treaty on plastics pollution, including in the oceans, by the end of 2024. (Image credit: Ahn Young-joon)

Title: Photos: See inside the Bidens' last White House Christmas
Description: More than 300 volunteers spent the past week decorating the White House's public spaces and its 83 Christmas trees with nearly 10,000 feet of ribbon, more than 28,000 ornaments, over 2,200 paper doves and some 165,000 lights used on wreaths, garlands and other displays, according to the Associated Press. (Image credit: Sofia Seidel)

Title: Joe Biden pardons his son. Is that justice?
Description: Hunter Biden no longer has to worry about going to prison.That's because his father President Joe Biden pardoned him with just weeks left in his presidency. The President's son was convicted in June on federal gun charges. Hunter Biden lied about his addiction to crack cocaine when he purchased a gun. And he pleaded guilty in September for failing to pay more than a million dollars in federal taxes.The younger Biden was due to be sentenced in both cases later this month.President Biden has granted his son a sweeping pardon. What will that mean for his legacy... and for the future of presidential pardons? For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.or...

Title: At Supreme Court, vaping may be frowned upon, but that could change with Trump
Description: The focal point of the case is 2009 law enacted by Congress that gives the Food and Drug Administration a mandate to curb the availability of nicotine products for minors. (Image credit: Michael M. Santiago)

Title: Tomorrow is Giving Tuesday. Here's how to pick a charity to donate to
Description: Tomorrow is Giving Tuesday, a day when charities ask us to take a break from holiday shopping and give to worthy causes. But picking a charity that aligns with your values comes with questions.

Title: Syria's president vows to launch counter-offensive after losing Aleppo to rebels
Description: In Syria, where government forces and rebel fighters have essentially been locked in a stalemate for over a decade, an unexpected opposition — a Turkish-backed group — has taken over.

Title: EX-Kansas police detective accused of sex crimes is found dead on day of trial
Description: A white ex-police detective from Kansas City accused of sexually assaulting Black women and girls was found dead Monday — the same day his federal trial was set to begin in Topeka.

Title: Rebels Make Surprise Advances in Syria. Who are They and What Does it Mean?
Description: Syria's bloody civil war against the government of Bashar al-Assad started in 2011 but it had been in a stalemate for years. All that changed recently when rebels lead by a group called Hayat Tahrir al-Sham rapidly routed government forces seizing the second most populous Syria city, Aleppo. We hear reaction from Syrians and about the group behind the revival of the conflict. Support NPR and get sponsor-free episodes of State of the World. Sign up for NPR+ at plus.npr.orgOr donate to NPR this Giving Tuesday at donate.npr.org

Title: In northern Israel, wary residents wait to see if a fragile ceasefire will hold
Description: In the first week of the ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon, residents from northern towns in Israel are trying to restart their lives.

Title: Biden isn't the first president to pardon a relative. Here's how the power works
Description: Biden is now the third president to pardon a relative, after Bill Clinton and Donald Trump. Here's a look at the commonplace — yet often controversial — presidential power. (Image credit: Mandel Ngan)

Title: U.N. stops sending aid through main Gaza crossing because route is too dangerous
Description: The main U.N. agency in Gaza has stopped picking up aid from a key Israeli border crossing -- saying it's impossible to collect the aid because of hurdles from Israeli authorities and lack of safety.

Title: Who are the rebels who have seized control of Aleppo, Syria?
Description: Syrian rebels have swept through parts of the country at lightning pace, taking control of the the second-largest city, Aleppo. But who are they and what are their aims? (Image credit: Omar Haj Kadour)

Title: FDA battles vaping industry at the Supreme Court
Description: The justices will hear arguments about the FDA's rejection of some e-cigarettes. High schoolers are at the center of the case. (Image credit: Scott Olson/Getty Images)

Title: Crash prevention technology shows 'huge potential,' but the roadmap is up for debate
Description: Nearly all new cars now come with automatic emergency braking and other safety features. Researchers say these systems are saving lives, but there's still debate about how to make them better. (Image credit: Dan Purdy)

Title: President Biden makes long awaited trip to Africa
Description: President Biden makes his first and only trip to Africa in his presidency, as he travels to Cabo Verde and Angola. (Image credit: Ben Curtis)

Title: Biden's Africa trip is an effort to counter China's influence on the continent
Description: President Biden makes the first trip of his presidency to Africa, as he travels to Cape Verde and Angola.

Title: Syria's president vows to crush rebels who have seized much of Aleppo
Description: Syrian government and Russian planes intensify airstrikes on rebel group who have taken over Syria's second city Aleppo in a lightning assault.

Title: Why there's a shortage of staff to work with special education students
Description: Staff who work with special education students are sometimes injured by students. That can make it harder to fill staff vacancies, at a time when there's already a nationwide shortage.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: President Biden pardons his son Hunter. President-elect Trump says he'll nominate Kash Patel to serve as the next FBI director. Syria's president vows to crush rebels who seized much of Aleppo.

Title: Local police face pressure to help carry out migrant deportations
Description: A new North Carolina law requires sheriffs to hold undocumented immigrants in jail for ICE to pick up. It's part of the dance state and federal powers must do to carry out Trump's deportation plans.

Title: A landmark climate change case will open at the top U.N. court
Description: The hearings come after years of lobbying by island nations who fear they could simply disappear under rising sea waters, (Image credit: Peter Dejong)

Title: What Trump team's Christian Zionism beliefs mean for Gaza war, West Bank settlements
Description: Mike Huckabee and Peter Hegseth have espoused strong Christian Zionism beliefs, which hold that Israel's existence is tied to biblical prophecy and the Second Coming of Christ.

Title: Hong Kong launches panda sculpture tour as the city hopes the bear craze boosts tourism
Description: Thousands of giant panda sculptures will greet residents and tourists starting Saturday in Hong Kong, where enthusiasm for the bears has grown since two cubs were born in a local theme park. (Image credit: Chan Long Hei)

Title: The International Criminal Court is facing doubts as its member states meet
Description: The court faces pushback over arrest warrants for Israeli officials, sexual harassment allegations against the court's chief prosecutor and a very empty docket. (Image credit: Peter Dejong)

Title: President Biden pardons son Hunter
Description: President Biden pardoned his son, reversing a previous pledge and saying 'it is clear that Hunter was treated differently' than others in the justice system. (Image credit: Jose Luis Magana)

Title: Belgium becomes first country to give sex workers robust labor rights and protections
Description: The new law guarantees fundamental rights for sex workers, including the ability to refuse clients, set the conditions of an act, and stop an act at any moment. (Image credit: Antoine Boureau)

Title: Prosecutors file motion to dismiss Jan. 6 case against Trump
Description: The move was widely expected after Trump's election victory, and is in line with longstanding Justice Department policy that says a sitting president cannot be indicted or tried on criminal charges. (Image credit: Saul Loeb)

Title: Macy's says an employee hid as much as $154 million in expenses
Description: The employee 'intentionally made erroneous accounting accrual entries' to hide millions of dollars, Macy's said. The error forced the company to delay reporting its third quarter results. (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Title: Ocean explorers hoped they photographed Amelia Earhart's plane. Turns out it's a rock
Description: Earhart, her navigator and their plane disappeared during their attempted 1937 circumnavigation of the globe. A deep sea exploration company thought it might have solved the mystery, but it lives on. (Image credit: Uncredited)

Title: The man who helped roll back abortion rights now wants to 'crush liberal dominance'
Description: Leonard Leo of the Federalist Society helped overturn abortion rights. He spoke to Morning Edition about his plans to disrupt Hollywood, Silicon Valley and other perceived centers of liberal thinking through the Teneo Network. (Image credit: Carolyn Kaster/AP)

Title: After 15 years, Megan Atherton reunites with her 'Unsung Hero'
Description: A special reunion conversation between Megan Atherton and the woman who changed the course of her life. (Image credit: Megan Atherton)

Title: Plastic waste is everywhere. Countries have one more chance to agree on a solution
Description: Negotiations over a U.N. treaty to cut plastics have been bogged down. Environmental groups blame the oil and gas industry. (Image credit: Christopher Furlong)

Title: Romania in shock after far-right populist enters presidential election's runoff
Description: Romania's political landscape is reeling after a little-known, far-right populist secured the first round in the presidential election, going from an obscure candidate to beating the incumbent prime minister. (Image credit: Alexandru Dobre)

Title: U.N. report: A woman or girl is killed every 10 minutes by a family member, partner
Description: A U.N. report shows rates are rising despite efforts for more severe penalties for targeted murders of women. The majority of female homicides are committed by an intimate partner or a family member.

Title: U.N. report: A woman or girl is killed every 10 minutes by her intimate partner
Description: A U.N. report shows rates are rising despite efforts for more severe penalties for targeted murders of women. The majority of female homicides are committed by an intimate partner or a family member.

Title: Some young Israelis choose to go to jail rather than fight in Gaza
Description: Military service is mandatory in Israel, but the war in Gaza has led some young Israelis to reject this obligation. A small number of young Israelis after choosing jail over the draft.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: President-elect Donald Trump announces more Cabinet picks. U.N. report says a woman or girl was killed every 10 minutes in 2023. Climate conference ends with a deal to help developing countries.

Title: Adultery is no longer illegal in New York
Description: It was considered a Class B misdemeanor, which carries a jail sentence of up to three months. (Image credit: Angela Weiss)

Title: Foreign ministers meet in Italy for the last G7 of the Biden administration
Description: Foreign ministers from the world's leading industrialized nations are meeting Monday, with a certain pressure to advance diplomatic efforts ahead of the new U.S. administration taking over. (Image credit: Andrew Medichini)

Title: New Zealanders help save about 30 whales after a pod strands on a beach
Description: New Zealand is a whale stranding hotspot. It's often not clear why they happen but the island nation's geography is believed to be a factor. (Image credit: Nikki Hartley)

Title: Should sex abuse evidence set the Menendez brothers free? A judge will decide.
Description: A judge will decide Monday whether new evidence warrants a re-examination of the convictions of Erik and Lyle Menendez in the shotgun murders of their parents 30 years ago. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Uruguay's leftist opposition candidate becomes country's new president
Description: The election was free of the anti-establishment fury that has vaulted populist outsiders to power elsewhere, like the United States and neighboring Argentina. (Image credit: Natacha Pisarenko)

Title: 2 Dartmouth fraternity members and a sorority have been charged in death of a student
Description: The Alpha Phi sorority and two members of Beta Alpha Omega have been charged after a student was found dead in a river after attending an off-campus party where alcohol was allegedly served to minors. (Image credit: Charles Krupa)

Title: Israeli strike kills Lebanese soldier as Hezbollah fires rockets at Israel
Description: An Israeli strike on a Lebanese army center on Sunday killed one soldier and wounded 18 others, the Lebanese military said. (Image credit: Oded Balilty/AP)

Title: Trump announces three medical doctors as his picks for the FDA, CDC and Surgeon-General
Description: President-elect Donald Trump announced three medical doctors as his picks to lead the FDA, CDC and to serve as surgeon general. NPR's Pien Huang discusses his picks.

Title: Israeli strike targets the heart of Beirut, killing 20 people
Description: There was a rare airstrike in the heart of Lebanon's capital Saturday. Israeli media say it was targeting a Hezbollah leader.

Title: Anti-Trump Republicans find themselves in a political no man's land after Trump's win
Description: With some contacting attorneys and others looking to move out of the country, anti-Trump Republicans are trying to figure out what's next after betting against the president-elect. (Image credit: Ali Khaligh)

Title: Russia is using new technology in its attacks on Ukraine
Description: Attacks between Ukraine and Russia are escalating, with Russia using what it describes as new missile technology.

Title: As Israel cuts ties with UNRWA, Palestinian refugees could lose vital services
Description: Israel has voted to end cooperation with UNRWA, the United Nations agency providing aid to Palestinian refugees. The move threatens key services for hundreds of thousands of refugees in the West Bank.

Title: San Francisco's incoming mayor has never held public office. That's part of his appeal
Description: San Francisco's new mayor, Daniel Lurie, has never held public office before. What does his win indicate about how voters are feeling about homelessness and other big issues the city is facing?

Title: Louisiana's faith groups are divided over a state law but work together for the community
Description: In Louisiana, religious leaders disagree over a state law that requires every public school classroom to display the Ten Commandments but still work together to address community needs.

Title: A photographer's devastating documentation of El Salvador's civil war in the 1980s
Description: In Legacy of Lies, El Salvador 1981-1984, photojournalist Robert Nickelsberg documents how U.S. foreign policy fueled a violent 13-year civil war in El Salvador. (Image credit: Robert Nickelsberg)

Title: With talks teetering, climate negotiators struck a controversial $300 billion deal
Description: Representatives of developing countries and climate activists were furious over the outcome, saying $300 billion annually from industrialized countries is far short of what vulnerable nations need to better protect themselves from climate change. (Image credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images)

Title: Now in overtime, UN climate talks continue
Description: UN climate negotiations are in overtime in Azerbiajan as countries scramble to land a deal on how to finance the damages brought on by climate change. The impacts often are felt most by poor countries that have contributed the least to global warming.

Title: A program in D.C. raised the wages of child care workers. How's it going now?
Cousins divided on abortion find ways to support each other
Description: One believes in total abortion rights. The other is against abortion in all circumstances. They're cousins, as close as sisters, and have come together with understanding on this truly divisive topic.

Title: Alcohol poisoning deaths in Laos renew concerns about methanol. Here's what to know
Description: The U.S., Australia and U.K. have issued warnings for travelers in Vang Vieng after several tourists died in a suspected methanol poisoning outbreak. (Image credit: Anupam Nath)

Title: Winter storms sweep across the U.S. while a new system is expected for Thanksgiving
Description: A major storm dropped more snow and record rain in California, while on the opposite side of the country blizzard or winter storm warnings were in effect Saturday. (Image credit: Noah Berger)

Title: NATO head and Trump meet in Florida for talks on global security
Description: U.S. President-elect Donald Trump and the head of NATO, Mark Rutte, met on Friday in Palm Beach for talks on global security, the military alliance said Saturday. (Image credit: Alex Brandon)

Title: What Trump's pick for secretary of defense could mean for inclusivity in the military
Description: The Trump administration nominee for secretary of defense calls women in combat roles a mistake. Critics fear it's yet another signal that policies that engage with a changing America could be on the chopping block.

Title: Biden administration urges states to move forward with Colorado River sharing agreement
Description: The seven states that share the Colorado River have a 2026 deadline for a new sharing agreement. The Biden administration this week encouraged them to hurry, in an apparent attempt to limit the incoming Trump administration's influence.

Title: Janet Martin, Mayor of the Armitage Brown Line station, retires after 29 years
Description: Janet Martin, aka the Mayor of Armitage Brown Line Station, is retiring from the Chicago Transit Authority after a 29-year career marked with kindness.

Title: Bringing Thanksgiving food on a plane? Here is what you should know
Description: Thanksgiving favorites such as mac and cheese, turkey and casseroles can be brought through TSA checkpoints. But cranberry sauce, maple syrup and gravy must go in checked baggage, the agency says. (Image credit: Transportation Security Administration)

Title: South Africa's illegal gold miners are locked in an underground standoff with police
Description: Surviving on a diet of toothpaste and toilet paper, South Africa's notorious 'zama-zama' illegal miners continue a weeks-long standoff with police in the darkness of a disused gold mine. (Image credit: Shiraaz Mohamed)

Title: Trump's deportation vow alarms Texas construction industry
Description: Texas builders warn mass deportations of undocumented migrants could devastate the construction industry, threatening housing and infrastructure work in one of the nation's fastest-growing states. (Image credit: John Moore)

Title: At least 11 killed in Israeli strikes in Beirut as diplomats push for cease-fire
Description: The strikes were the fourth on Beirut in less than a week. The escalation comes after a U.S. envoy traveled to the region this week in an attempt to broker a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah. (Image credit: Hassan Ammar)

Title: Atmospheric rivers aren't new. Why does it feel like we're hearing about them more?
Description: In recent years, 'atmospheric river' has become used much more frequently in scientific papers and in media coverage. According to experts who study climate and weather, a few reasons may explain why. (Image credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images)

Title: NATO and Ukraine to hold emergency talks after Russia's attack with new missile
Description: NATO and Ukraine will hold emergency talks Tuesday after Russia attacked the city of Dnipro with an experimental, hypersonic ballistic missile that escalated the nearly 33-month-old war. (Image credit: Vyacheslav Prokofyev/AP)

Title: Trump names former Texas state Rep. Scott Turner to lead Housing and Urban Development
Description: HUD is bracing for possible budget cuts, something the first Trump administration proposed but was unable to get through Congress. Other changes could restrict who gets rental aid. (Image credit: Alastair Pike)

Title: The ICC's arrest warrant for Israel's Netanyahu highlights international divisions
Description: The International Criminal Court's decision to issue arrest warrants for Israel's prime minister, its former defense minister and a senior military leader of Hamas has exposed deep global divisions.

Title: Palestinian olive farmers face violence from settlers and security forces
Description: Olive harvesting in the West Bank has become increasingly dangerous as Palestinian farmers face a rise in violence by Israeli settlers and security forces.

Title: Mass deportations would hurt families and Texas' construction industry, many say
Description: The migrant workforce is vital to construction across Texas. Now, the industry is bracing for Trump's expected crackdown on illegal immigration, including plans to carry out mass deportations.

Title: A Relationship Surviving 1,000 Days of War
Description: It has been over a thousand days since Russia began it's full-scale invasion of Ukraine. The war has had huge geopolitical ramifications, but it has also has affected the lives of millions of ordinary people. Our correspondent in Kyiv tells us how the one couple in Ukraine has weathered the conflict. (Image credit: Claire Harbage)

Title: Wisconsin kayaker who faked his death has resurfaced in Europe after elaborate plot
Description: Wisconsin authorities say they have not yet issued a warrant for Ryan Borgwardt, who is believed to be somewhere in Eastern Europe. But that can change if he does not cooperate and return home soon. (Image credit: Green Lake County Sheriff's Office via AP)

Title: Jonathan Majors and ex-girlfriend Grace Jabbari settle assault and defamation case
Description: In a civil lawsuit this spring, the actor's former girlfriend alleged a 'pattern of pervasive domestic abuse' in addition to defamation. Her legal team said the suit has been settled. (Image credit: Richard Shotwell)

Title: University of Texas, MIT and others announce free tuition for some undergraduates
Description: Nearly half a dozen institutions of higher education announced plans this week to make tuition free for undergraduates whose families make below a certain income threshold, starting in fall 2025.
